title: Rapid Biodegradation of the Organophosphorus Insecticide Chlorpyrifos by Cupriavidus nantongensis X1T
authors: Taozhong Shi, Liancheng Fang, Han Qin, Yifei Chen, Xiangwei Wu, Rimao Hua
journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
keyAssumptions: Bacterial chlorpyrifos degradation is inherently slow; TCP accumulation limits complete mineralization
citation: Shi, T., Fang, L., Qin, H., Chen, Y., Wu, X., & Hua, R. (2019). Rapid biodegradation of the organophosphorus insecticide chlorpyrifos by Cupriavidus nantongensis X1T. Int J Environ Res Public Health, 16(23), 4593.
notes: Breakthrough study demonstrating 100-fold faster degradation than previous best strain. Challenges speed limitation assumptions with 200 mg/L degraded in 48h.

title: Insights into the microbial degradation and catalytic mechanisms of chlorpyrifos
authors: Yaohua Huang, Wenping Zhang, Shimei Pang, Junmin Chen, Pankaj Bhatt, Sandhya Mishra, Shaohua Chen
keyAssumptions: Degradation mechanisms are strain-specific; Enzymatic mechanisms poorly understood
citation: Huang, Y., Zhang, W., Pang, S., Chen, J., Bhatt, P., Mishra, S., & Chen, S. (2021). Insights into the microbial degradation and catalytic mechanisms of chlorpyrifos. Environmental Research, 194, 110322.
notes: Comprehensive review establishing universal serine-mediated nucleophilic attack mechanism across diverse microbial degraders. Key mechanistic framework.

title: Biodegradation of chlorpyrifos using isolates from contaminated agricultural soil, its kinetic studies
keyAssumptions: Laboratory strains perform similarly in field conditions; Single environmental factors control performance
citation: Wahid, A., et al. (2021). Biodegradation of chlorpyrifos using isolates from contaminated agricultural soil, its kinetic studies. Scientific Reports, 11, 9721.
notes: Demonstrates importance of indigenous soil isolates and statistical optimization. Bacillus cereus Ct3 shows superior environmental adaptability with 88% degradation.

title: Degradation insight of organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos through novel intermediate 2,6-dihydroxypyridine by Arthrobacter sp. HM01
keyAssumptions: TCP is primary intermediate; Degradation pathways are well-characterized
citation: Subramanian, R.B., et al. (2022). Degradation insight of organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos through novel intermediate 2,6-dihydroxypyridine by Arthrobacter sp. HM01. Bioresources and Bioprocessing, 9, 31.
notes: Discovery of novel degradation intermediate challenges pathway assumptions. Fastest reported degradation (99% in 10h) with unprecedented chlorpyrifos tolerance (1000 mg/L).

title: Strategies in microbial degradation enhancement of chlorpyrifos – a review based on the primary approaches in soil bioremediation
authors: Edna Mary Varghese, Aswani P., Jisha M.S.
keyAssumptions: Single-strain approaches are sufficient; Simple systems preferred over complex ones
citation: Varghese, E.M., Aswani, P., & Jisha, M.S. (2021). Strategies in microbial degradation enhancement of chlorpyrifos – a review based on the primary approaches in soil bioremediation. Bioremediation Journal, 25(3), 187-210.
notes: Comprehensive framework integrating biostimulation, bioaugmentation, and immobilization. Challenges single-strain paradigm with systematic enhancement approaches.

title: Biodegradation of Chlorpyrifos by Enterobacter Strain B-14 and Its Use for Bioremediation of Contaminated Soils
authors: B.K. Singh, A. Walker, J.A.W. Morgan, D.J. Wright
keyAssumptions: Chlorpyrifos is inherently persistent; Natural degraders do not exist
citation: Singh, B.K., Walker, A., Morgan, J.A.W., & Wright, D.J. (2003). Biodegradation of chlorpyrifos by Enterobacter strain B-14 and its use for bioremediation of contaminated soils. Applied and Environmental Microbiology, 69(9), 5198-5206.
notes: Landmark foundational study establishing proof-of-concept for chlorpyrifos biodegradation. First systematic isolation and characterization of degrading bacteria.
